Introduction

I have been buying technical books from The Pragmatic Bookshelf for 20 years (!), so when a new release about AI Engineering popped up, I was all over it.

A Common-Sense Guide to AI Engineering, authored by Jay Wengrow is still in Beta release, but itâ€™s a pretty amazing overview of AI development principles. At some point I should probably do a book review, but for now Iâ€™ll simply say buy the book!

Setting Up My Development Environment

  • Create An OpenAI Account

The author uses various LLMs developed by OpenAI, and you donâ€™t get to use OpenAIâ€™s API for free, so the first order of business was to set up an OpenAI account. The good news: you can set up an account with a $5 minimum, which is more than enough to fund a bit of experimentation. So far I have only burned through about $2.

  • Set Up A Pinecone Account

Chapter 6 and 7 provide basic concepts concerning Retrieval-Augmentaion Generation (RAG). RAG uses something called a vector database, and Pinecone is a company that provides a free tier for experimentation purposes. So I created a Pinecone account using my GitHub credentials.

  • Set Up A Python Development Environment

All of the code examples in the book are based upon Python. I have very limited experience with Python, but 20+ years of Ruby development allows me to understand most of whatâ€™s happening in the code, and I can make educated guesses about the rest.

I decided to use LazyVim as my development framework, as it understands the Python (version 3.12.3) ecosystem out of the box.

The OS is Ubuntu 24.04 running as a VMWare image on my obsolete MacBook Air machine. Not the most ideal setup, but it works for nowâ€¦

First Steps - Build a Terminal-Based Chatbot

An hourâ€™s worth of reading and 32 lines of Python code, and I had a working chatbot that talks like a pirate. Hilariousâ€¦

Note: not being a Python developer, I am using Wengrowâ€™s code pretty much verbatum, so in order to respect the authorâ€™s work I am not going to reproduce the code here. Buy the book! But I will reproduce the output from the chatbots.

AI Chatbot - The Pirate

  • model: gpt-4.1-mini

The prompt contains:

"content": "You are an AI assistant who always talks like a pirate."},

Awesomeâ€¦

AI Chatbot - The Hippie

  • model: gpt-4.1-mini

Modifying the prompt to:

"content": "You are an AI assistant who always talks like a 1960's Flower Child."},

yields:

Far out, manâ€¦

AI Chatbot - Generic

  • model: gpt-4.1-nano

and then with a simple prompt:

"content": "You are a helpful AI assistant."},

we get:

Factually correct, but boringâ€¦

Discussion

If you look at the gpt-4.1-nano information page, there are (among others) three important metrics: context window, max output tokens and knowledge cutoff date.

These items are discussed in the book, and thatâ€™s why this query failed:

I also ran into the max token limit whilst noodling around with other queries. It created a Python program crash that was a bit difficult to read and interpret. A more robust version of the program should include better error detection.

Conclusions

This was actually a lot of fun and was the result of studying Chapters 1 - 5 of Wengrowâ€™s work. I was surprised at how straightforward it was to get everything up and running. Having an author who knows how to write clear and concise technical information was a big factor, no doubt.

In Part 3 (Chapter 12) the author starts working with AI agents. This is where it gets really interesting, and Iâ€™ll cover my results in a separate blog, i.e. AI Experiments Part 2.
